10.8.5 Training Schedule
The training modules are combined into different training components. There are overlaps in the
composition of the target groups and the constitution of the training components. However, each
training module would need to be developed keeping in view the composition and responsibilities of
the target group members. The training schedule for the various target groups would be as given in
Table 10.1 below.

10.8.6 Imparting Training
It is proposed that the training be imparted by a combination of training/academic institutions and
individual experts. It would further be important to bring in trainers experienced in implementing EMPs
in developing countries and who are experts in the environmentally sound road construction
techniques and processes.
10.8.7 Further Assessment of Training Needs
The training needs assessment herein has been part of an all-encompassing assignment. It is
recommended that a full-fledged training need assessment (with respect to environmental capacity
building of the NHAI) be carried out. Looking at the potential work programme of NHAI in the next few
years, this exercise is of paramount importance.
Institutional capacity building should continue even after the requisite manpower described in the
preceding sections has been recruited and an Environmental Wing is operational. Once the training
envisaged in the TNHP's training schedule and budget has been completed for all stakeholders, the
NHAI can move on to upgrading the skills of its core professionals. A two-pronged approach is
suggested for the training modules under the GTRP. Intensive training on issues related with
environmental monitoring along highways will become an important issue for the ground level
implementation staff. On the other hand, the staff at HQ level will receive extensive training in areas
related to policy-based issues like road planning. The target groups for the GTRP's proposed training
will be reduced since some part of the training has already been budgeted for in the TNHP. The help
from extemal experts is also expected to diminish as the Environmental Wing staff increases in
numbers, confidence and skills.
The intensive training on pollution monitoring will build on Module Xl of the TNHP. With equipment
available in-house, emphasis will now be on hands-on training. Instead of just recording and passing
on the data to the CNHAI, PIU staff will find out about the end use of the data. It is expected that this
training in pollution monitoring and In use of data collected for the GIS system already described
earlier, will go a long way in ensuring that the data collection is streamlined and efficient. Routine
maintenance of the equipment to be used on site, such as calibration after repeated use will also be
covered. Additional short-term training can Include improved report writing and presentation skills to
facilitate clear communication between the various PlUs and the CNHAI. Intensive training would
build up competence in areas like impacts on ecosystems, cumulative impacts etc. only touched upon
during the introductory training sessions of the TNHP.
The more policy/strategy level training for the CNHAI officials will incorporate regional concerns albeit
on a very broad-brush level. Implications of proposed road development on regional basis and the
feedback of such development on the planning of new roads, implications of improved road conditions
and suppressed demand and consequent environmental impacts, global warming implications of
motorised transportation will be covered.
Trainers with first-hand knowledge of implementing and maintaining highways projects will be
procured from all over the world to impart knowledge on these very specialized areas. It is important
that the best in the field are hired for the purpose. In addition, sustained interaction with leading
organizations in the field of highway implementation and maintenance will help exchange ideas with
those at the forefront of technological development. Alternatively, some members of the NHAI staff
would be sent abroad (to a developed country) for training. It is proposed that the Manager
(Environment) who performs best on the training modules conducted as part of the TNHP. The
candidate institutions/organizations would include TRRL, UK and FHWA, USA where the official/s
would be able to gain first hand knowledge of the latest highway management and maintenance
L. Asoc D.
10-19



ConsoWkdated EIA Report
Grand Trunk Road Profct
techniques. It should be emphasized that the consideration for selection to future courses will be
contingent upon measurable improvement in performance on the job after return from the
training/tour.The possible areas in which training from these countries would be of help are the use of
models for impact prediction and their calibration under different conditions, the implications of road
projects on development plans, etc. Other Issues, which could be addressed under shorter
programmes, include emergency response planning, facilities siting and maintenance along highways,
etc.
In addition, refresher courses are proposed to cover environmental management issues like drainage,
wildlife protection. An Interesting course could deal with review of environmental Impact assessment
statements. In addition, periodic visits within India to sites of other highway projects like those under
state PWDs would give fresh insights in planning, implementation and maintenance of
mItIgatIon/enhancement measures. Follow-up activity after each training should include a circulation
of a brief written note, or a presentation to the Environment Wing of the NHAI followed by a short
question and answer session about the merits of the course.
10.8.8 Training Budget
The total budget required for implementing the training programme is Rs10.1 million. The details of
the training budget are provided in Table 10.2.

The resources for implementing the training programme are available mainly from the environmental
budget of the project. The training budget has been incorporated and equally apportioned to the
environmental budget for the different contract packages.
However, as part of the project, a separate overall training budget is proposed. This budget for
(overall) training will be available for training of the NHAI and the MoST Engineers through the NITHE,
New Delhi. Part of the US$3 million budget would be used for capacity building of NITHE and trainers'
training. .A part of such budget will be available for environmental training also. It may therefore be
useful to amalgamate resources from both the (project's) environmental budget and the (overall)
training budget.
